text: early evening on tuesday boris johnson
released a statement
today i've received a
fixed penalty notice from the
metropolitan police relating to an event
in downing street on the 19th of june
2020 and let me say immediately that
i've paid the fine and i once again
offer a full
apology four months ago on the 8th of
december boris johnson had also
addressed the issue of lockdown parties
in downing street i can understand
how infuriating it must be to think that
the people who have been setting the
rules have not been following the rules
but one of the people who was setting
the rules and not following them was the
prime minister the police say they
believe mr johnson his wife carrie
simmons and chancellor rishi sunak all
broke the law all three would be fined
and downing street shared a police
statement issued to mr johnson in which
he's told on the 19th of june 2020 at
the cabinet room 10 downing street
between 1400 and 1500 he participated in
a gathering of two or more people
indoors this was a birthday gathering
reported by the times and then by itv
news itv told us the prime minister
received cake whilst his wife laid a
staff in a course of happy birthday and
that those assembled are understood to
have eaten picnic food from m s the
mirror has since reported the police
have a bombshell picture which shows
boris johnson holding a can of beer at a
lockdown birthday party the police
haven't confirmed that but several days
before this gathering we know mr johnson
urged people to show restraint and
respect the rules but to his supporters
this rule-breaking gathering was not his
fault in january the minister conor
burns told channel 4 it was not a
premeditated organized party he was in a
sense ambushed with a cake
cake ambusher otherwise the police
believe boris johnson broke the law to
which this is mr johnson's response in
all frankness at that time
it did not occur to me
that this might have been a breach of
the rules but of course the police have
found otherwise and i
fully respect the outcome
of their investigation that may be but
while mr johnson says he's always sought
to tell the truth the police's
conclusion means that he repeatedly made
false statements about these lockdown
parties for example just after the story
broke the prime minister said this
all guidance was followed completely
during number 10. that wasn't true nor
was it true the next day when the prime
minister spokesperson said all covered
rules have been followed at all times
nor is it true when mr johnson said this
on the 7th of december the guidelines
were followed at all times the
guidelines weren't followed at all times
and in that same interview mr johnson
was asked if he was sure did you
investigate that yourself have you
satisfied yourself i have satisfied
myself that the guidelines were followed
at
mr johnson was satisfied but a leaked
video showed that back in late 2020 his
colleagues were practicing how to answer
questions about a party that had
recently happened i apologize for
uh for the impression that has been
given uh that staff and danny street
take this less than seriously uh i'm i
i'm sickened myself and furious about
that mr johnson was furious about the
impression that staff were not taking
the issue of lockdown gathering
seriously but the police have now
concluded that he and his chancellor
attended one despite this assurance from
rishi sunak nova speaker i did not
attend any parties
and now that the police have decided
that he did attend a gathering the
opposition has seen enough labour's
leader sakia stamina tweeted boris
johnson and rishi sunak have broken the
law and repeatedly lied to the british
public they must both resign now the
prime minister denies lying and if
that's labour's criticism then this is
the liberal democrats we will see if
conservative mps
really believe that having a prime
minister who breaks the law
having a chance exchequer who breaks the
law
is acceptable so far it is acceptable
there's no evidence of a move against
boris johnson even sir roger gail who
called for him to go back in january now
tells itv we're in the middle of an
international crisis now is absolutely
not the time to destabilize the
government but a prime minister breaking
the law inevitably destabilizes to some
degree especially given the
circumstances because it was boris
johnson who ordered three lockdowns in
england at other times strict rules
remained in place and there were many
appeals such as this our plan does rely
on all of us continuing to make
sacrifices to protect those we love so
please please continue to follow the
rules loved ones though were lost
coveted death toll in the uk by the end
of 2020 was more than 76 000 by the end
of 2021 it was nearly 150 000 and some
of those who lost loved ones have
reacted to these fines one campaign
group tweeted after everything it's
still unbelievably painful that boris
johnson was partying and breaking his
own lockdown rules while we were unable
to be at loved ones sides in their dying
moments or in miserable funerals with
only a handful of people
we were following the rules they were
and we now know that the prime minister
wasn't not just that he was telling
parliament something different which
brings us to the ministerial code it
reads ministers who knowingly mislead
parliament will be expected to offer
their resignation if boris johnson knew
either he or someone else had broken the
rules this appears clear-cut but we
already know number 10's defense on this
back in march a spokesperson said at all
times he set out his understanding of
events and that defence has been echoed
by the prime minister on tuesday and by
the tory mp michael fabricant when he
went to the house and said i don't think
i was breaking any law
i don't think he did think he was
breaking any law this in turn would mean
the prime minister didn't fully
understand the laws that he was setting
as well as not knowing how others were
breaking the law inside number 10 and
whitehall because remember this isn't
just about one event the police are
investigating 12 of them they intend to
issue at least 50 fines and there's also
the investigation by the civil servant
sue gray her initial findings already
note failures of leadership and judgment
by different parts of number 10 and the
cabinet office at different times and
even without sue grey's report we know
the police believe the uk has a
law-breaking leader and a question asked
by boris johnson's predecessor theresa
may back in january remains relevant
either my right honourable friend had
not read the rules or didn't understand
what they meant and others around him or
they didn't think the rules applied to
number 10 which was it
while following news of his fine mr
johnson says he didn't know he was
breaking the rules and he added this i
understand the anger that many will feel
that i myself fell short when it came to
observing the very rules which the
government i lead had introduced
to protect the public and so a prime
minister who police believe broke the
law who offered assurances that have
turned out not to be true is now asking
his country and his party to trust him
to continue as their leader
